moves.2... Bf5: In queen pawn openings I have noticed that a great many players will move the queen bishop early, and this is a mistake, as I have mentioned many times in my chess lessons, because White will at the very least gain a tempo when he plays Qb3 later attacking the b7 pawn.
moves.4... Nxd5 5. Nc3: Better would have been 5. Nbd2 Nb6 6. e4
moves.7. Qb3: Now if 7... Qc7 8. e4 Bxe4 9. Ng5 Bg6 10. Bf4 Qxf4 11. Qxb7 e6 12. Bb5+ Kd8 13. Qxa8 Bd6 14. Nh3 Qf5 15. Qxa7 cxd4 16. Qb6+ Ke7 (16... Bc7 17. Qxd4+) 17. Qb7+ Kf6 18. cxd4
moves.7... Be4: White can win with 8. Ng5 Bg6  (Sidelining the bishop gives white this big advantage.) 9. e4 h6 10. Qxb7 Nd7 11. Bb5 Rc8 (11... Rb8 12. Bxd7+) 12. Nf3 Qc7 13. Qxc7 Rxc7 14. Bf4 Rb7 15. Ba4 Kd8 (15... Bxe4 16. dxc5 [with a winning game.]) 16. Rd1 c4 17. Ne5 Nb6 (17... Nb8 18. Ke2 Kc8 (18... Bxe4 19. Nxf7+) 19. f3 e6 20. Rb1 Rxb1 (20... Bd6 21. Nxg6) 21. Rxb1 Na6 22. Bd7+ Kd8 23. Rb7 Nc7 24. Nxg6) 18. Bc6
This move is simply wrong.  White tries too hard to press the advantage, thinking that after cxd4 he could play a combination of Ba6 and Bf4, forgetting that Bf4 black can meet with e5. 

Instead 13. e3 is simple and winning.
moves.13... cxd4: White's best chance is 14. cxd4 Nxd4 15. Rb1 Bc5 16. Ba6  equal.
moves.14... Rb8: Now 15. a4 dxc3 16. Bb5 Rc8  is close to equal.
moves.15. O-O dxc3: The problem with White's failed plan is that this pawn on c3 is winning for black.
moves.16. Be3 Be7:
Definitely the wrong square. 

16... Ba3 is winning. 17. Bc4 O-O 18. Bb3 e5 19. Rad1 Nd4 20. Bxd4 exd4 21. Rf2 (21. Rxd4 Bc5) (21. Kh1 Rfd8 22. Rd3 Rxb3 23. axb3 c2) 21... Bc5 22. Kf1 d3 23. Rxd3 Bxf2 24. Kxf2 Rfc8 25. Rd1 a5 26. Rc1 (26. Ke3 a4 27. Bxa4 Rb2 28. Bb3 Rxg2) 26... Rb4 27. Ke3 a4 28. Bd1 a3 29. Kd3 Rb2 30. Bb3 (30. Bc2 Rxa2) (30. Rc2 Rd8+) 30... Rd2+ 31. Ke3 Rxg2 32. h4 Rh2
moves.17. Rab1: Much better is 17. Rac1 Bb4 18. Rfd1 O-O 19. a3 Ba5 20. Rd6  equal.
moves.17... O-O:
Black is still winning. 

Now 18. Rxb8 Rxb8 19. Rc1 Is the best chance.
moves.22. Rc1: Now 22... Bf6  and the game is over. 23. a3 Bb2 24. axb4 Bxc1 25. Bxc1 Rc3 26. Ba4 Rd3 27. Bxc2 Rc3
moves.23. Bd2: Now Black could get really clever with  23... Nxa2 24. Bxa2 (24. Bxc3 Nxc1) 24... Ba3 25. Bxc3 Bxc1 26. Kf1 Be3 27. Bb2 c1=Q+ 28. Bxc1 Bxc1 staying a pawn up, but this is likely a draw because of the bishops of opposite colors.
